contextId.information: These two phrases express the same idea to make the student pay attention. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: listen to me ... do not turn away from listening

contextId.information: These two phrases express the same idea and emphasize how much this person disliked what the teacher had said. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I hated instruction ... my heart despised correction

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The writer speaks of a man sleeping only with his wife as if he drank water only from his own cistern or well. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: water from your own cistern ... running water from your own well

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are repeated to show how responsible the ant is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: it prepares its food in the summer ... during the harvest it stores up what it will eat

contextId.information: The teacher uses these questions to scold the lazy person for sleeping too much. AT: "Wake up, you lazy person! Get out of your bed!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How long will you sleep ... When will you rise from your sleep?

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They can be stated as complete sentences. AT: "I will just sleep a little longer. Let me sleep lightly a little longer." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: A little sleep, a little slumber

contextId.information: These three phrases are used together to emphasize that the lessons are valuable all the time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: When you walk ... when you sleep ... when you wake up

contextId.information: The repetition of these phrases is to show that the lessons are valuable for all sorts of things. It also speaks of those lessons as if they were people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: they will guide you ... they will watch over you ... they will teach you

contextId.information: These two phrases basically mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize that the woman's victims will be destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: on the paths to Sheol ... down to the dark bedrooms of death

contextId.information: These two phrases basically say the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
These two phrases basically say the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Give to a wise person ... teach a righteous person

contextId.information: These two lines are parallel and it is implied that the man in the first line is a wise man. AT: "The words of a wise man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The words of a man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same and are repeated to emphasize how important it is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Listen to advice and accept instruction

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize the danger of too much alcohol. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Wine is a mocker and strong drink is a brawler
